Sr. Class Films reeling in debt
by Bradley Cohen
A history of losing money has
forced the senior class to curtail
its traditional weekend film
series.
The series, used by the seniors
to raise money to pay for a commencement speaker, has been losing money for over a year.
Faced with this problem,
Senior Class President Scott

FitzGerald took action by cutting
the number of movies shown to
one every other week and increasing the size of the group that
selects the movies.
"The WonderFlix shows hot
movies and we're going to also,"
said FitzGerald about Weekend
WonderFlix, a more successful
on-campus weekly film series.
Among the movies FitzGerald
seeks to bring to campus include.

those of Woody Allen and Alfred
Hitchcock.
FitzGerald expressed support
for continuing to maintain two
film series on campus, but added
that the Senior Class Film Series
"should be an [Student Activities
Commission] group starting next
year."
In the 1987-88 year, the film
series lost $1,200 while last
semester it lost $300. FitzGerald

attributed the losses of the film
series to poor attendance, poor
movie selection, and insufficient
promotion.
Changes appear to be on the
way, though. "We're going to
have a movie every other week
and work hard to promote it,"
said FitzGerald. We're going to
try to get as many people to go,
especially seniors. That way we
can make some money."

several major building projects

Many people might wonder: If

increase revenues?
The answer lies in the way in

thing called a university," says

business and finance at Northwestern. "That's central to the
success of our schools. None of
them can operate by themselves,
we feel, nor should they."

12, 13, 14...HIKE!
The annual announcement of a
University tuition increase may soon
rival Groundhog Day in its seasonal appeal for Hopkins students. Not unlike
the groundhog, University President
Steven Muller every February emerges
from his winter seclusion to face a barrage of onlookers, photographers, and
reporters, and reveal data. Accompanied by a motley assortment of deans,
directors, and assistants, both Muller
and the groundhog tend to their business
quickly and leave as soon as possible.
Rarely do Muller or the groundhog
reveal new concepts at these appearances. Spring inevitably comes, and
as we've seen, so does a tuition hike,
with or without the star players. Still,
we do count on them to supply the
necessary numerical details: how much
longer until spring'? and how much more
in tuition payments? And every now and
then, during a bad winter, say, or a bad
deficit, the details take on a special
significance.
In keeping with the 1988-1989 "bad
deficit," the details of this year's foray
were quite significant. The administration departed from tradition by proposing a two-tiered tuition system.
Although tuition will rise the customary
$1000 from $12000 to $13000, the 6%
increase will apply only to continuing
students. New incoming students will
pay $14000.
The two-tiered system would be a
"one-time action" to be phased out
when the last group of current students
leave or graduate. According to Lloyd
Armstrong, dean of the School of Arts
and Sciences, the decision stemmed
from the administration's commitment
to keep tuition in line with incoming
students' expectations.

Armstrong defended the increases
with familiar arguments. While the
"Tuition Fact Sheet" distributed at
previous meetings was thankfully abandoned this year, the dean attributed the
hike to rising costs and the relatively
low percentage of cost covered by tuition. Armstrong and Muller also pledged maintenance of financial aid.
And so the tradition continues.
The University's action is easy to attack popularly. After all, rising costs are
never welcome measures. Indeed, the
average undergraduate probably finds it
increasingly difficult to justify, if not
meet, the price of a private education.
On the other hand, if tuition actually
covers only a small proportion of the
price, as the administration's warmedover rhetoric implies, then it is difficult
to see what other choice administrators
have. Where will the difference come
from, if not in part from tuition? Clearly, maintaining that special Hopkins
quality is expensive, but letting it slide
would be even more costly.
Given that the University already considers undergraduates revenue raisers,
it is not a radical philosphical departure
to raise the amount each will pay. We
do applaud the two-tiered system. If the
tuition is to be raised, it is fair to allow
parents and students to adjust their expectations accordingly. After all, past
years have shown that tuition hikes,
however upsetting, are even more painful when more costly than anticipated.
So, it is with a sense of resignation
that we accept, however grudgingly, the
proposals that have been laid out before
us. In the final analysis, if we can continue our metaphor, the groundhog has
only a limited number of options to act
upon each time he comes out.

Quick: what's the hottest major around? No, it's not biology,
BME, or IR, but public health,
according to Public Health Advisor Charlotte Kaufman.
Public Health has become a national priority as the public has
become more aware of health
issues such as smoking, AIDS,
and the environment. Public

health is simply working for and
with the public to develop and
maintain good health.
At Hopkins, undergrads interested in public health can pursue the Public Health Option in
conjunction with a natural, social,
or behavioral sciences major.
The Public Health Option involves taking the usual science requirements as well as some
courses at the School of Public
Health and Hygiene. Kaufman

describes it as "an amazing opportunity for young people to
have, to be involved in a school
of this quality."
The School of Public Health is
the oldest and most prestigious
public health school in the world.
It has students from around the
United States as well as from over
50 other countries. Some of its
twelve departments are almost as
hard to get into as the medical
school across the street, par-

ticularly epidemiology, maternal
and child health, population
dynamics, and environmental
sciences.
Graduates of the School of
Public Health can find jobs
almost immediately due to the
overwhelming demand for public
health professionals, such as.
health administrators and
epidemiologists. And first-year
salaries range from $20,000
(nutritionist) to $30,000 (health
management) and higher. Past
public health school graduates are
CEO's, presidents of companies,
directors, administrators, managers, and consultants.
A Master's in public health can
also give an immense edge in applying to med school, not to mention much more skill and
knowledge in practice. Kaufman
advises anyone even thinking of
med school to consider public
health. And under the Public
Health Option, students can get to
know faculty members at the
School, giving them an edge over
their peers.
Students interested in public
health should first browse
through materials in 241

Merganthaler.

sophomore year, students should
have met with Kaufman to outline
options in detail. In their junior
year, students can apply for the
Bachelors/Masters program,
which guarantees admission to
the School and leaves half of the
senior year to starting progress
towards a Master's.
Even if students don't make it
into the School of Public Health,
there are 23 other public health
schools out there, including the
almost comparable Harvard,
Yale, Columbia, UC-Berkeley,
and Michigan.
Kaufman advises students to
consider public health early.
Kaufman, who has a Master's in
public health ('72), was Director
of Admissions and Registrar at
the School of Public Health from
1972-1986. She came to
Homewood this January and is
now the public health advisor.
Kaufman urges students to see
her. "We have this wonderful
resource that could be a life's opportunity for a number of
undergraduates who aren't quite
sure what they want to do."

By several measures of financial success, the Johns Hopkins
University appears to be doing
quite well. It reported a
$16-million surplus last year, has
raised more than $512-million in
private donations since 1984, and
ranks first among universities in
federal research support, with
nearly $500-million in grants and
contracts.
Nonetheless, Hopkins officials
recently announced a plan to cut
10 per cent of the arts-andsciences faculty, increase
undergraduate enrollment and tuition, and delay indefinitely
several major building projects
and academic ventures.
Many people might wonder: If
the university appears to be flush
with cash, why is it taking such
dramatic action to cut costs and
increase revenues?
The answer lies in the way in
which Johns Hopkins manages its
divisions. While most universities
control their finances centrally,
routinely using surpluses from
one division to cover another's
losses, Hopkins demands of its
divisions an unusual degree of
self-sufficiency.
Even though some divisions
may show profits, and even

though the university as a whole
may take in more money than it
spends, any division that does not
at least break even must cut its
costs and look for ways to raise
revenue.
That means, for example, that
professors in the School of Arts
and Sciences, which projects a
$7-million deficit this year, will
see lower pay raises for the next
five years than will their colleagues elsewhere in the university, while the School of
Medicine, with a $3-million
surplus, builds an $85-million
research facility (The Chronicle,
January 4).
While the cutbacks at Hopkins
are unusual, the financial system
it uses is not unique. Several
other large private institutions, including Harvard University, the
University of Miami, the University of Pennsylvania, the University of Southern California, and
Washington University, also encourage or require their individual schools to be financially
independent.
Each school that has such status
typically retains its own tuition,
gifts, grant money, and other
revenues, including income from
its share of the university endowment. At the same time, each
school must pay for its teaching
and staff costs, facilities and
equipment, overhead, central services like maintenance, and a
share of central administrative
costs.

Decentralization Has Its Risks
But decentralizaiton has its
risks, as the situation at Johns
Hopkins demonstrates. Critics
say the system encourages
needless competition among
academic divisions, contradicts
the collegial spirit of a university, and fosters a corporate mentality and profit motive where
none should exist. Decentralization, its critics say, also can accentuate distinctions between
haves and have-nots, the "rich"
and "poor" schools within a
university. And, the system can
confound those who must live
with its results.
"It's not as if we in the faculty
of arts and sciences made some
mistake, or spent beyond our
means," says a senior professor
at Hopkins.
Concern about inter-divisional
rivalries is one reason Northwestern University continues to
control its budget centrally, like
most universities, pooling most
revenues and making allocations
from a central office.
"We believe that there is a
thing called a university," says
Lee A. Ellis, vice-president for
business and finance at Northwestern. "That's central to the
success of our schools. None of
them can operate by themselves,
we feel, nor should they."

autonomy among their divisions

12, 13, 14...HIKE!
The annual announcement of a
University tuition increase may soon
rival Groundhog Day in its seasonal appeal for Hopkins students. Not unlike
the groundhog, University President
Steven Muller every February emerges
from his winter seclusion to face a barrage of onlookers, photographers, and
reporters, and reveal data. Accompanied by a motley assortment of deans,
directors, and assistants, both Muller
and the groundhog tend to their business
quickly and leave as soon as possible.
Rarely do Muller or the groundhog
reveal new concepts at these appearances. Spring inevitably comes, and
as we've seen, so does a tuition hike,
with or without the star players. Still,
we do count on them to supply the
necessary numerical details: how much
longer until spring'? and how much more
in tuition payments? And every now and
then, during a bad winter, say, or a bad
deficit, the details take on a special
significance.
In keeping with the 1988-1989 "bad
deficit," the details of this year's foray
were quite significant. The administration departed from tradition by proposing a two-tiered tuition system.
Although tuition will rise the customary
$1000 from $12000 to $13000, the 6%
increase will apply only to continuing
students. New incoming students will
pay $14000.
The two-tiered system would be a
"one-time action" to be phased out
when the last group of current students
leave or graduate. According to Lloyd
Armstrong, dean of the School of Arts
and Sciences, the decision stemmed
from the administration's commitment
to keep tuition in line with incoming
students' expectations.

Armstrong defended the increases
with familiar arguments. While the
"Tuition Fact Sheet" distributed at
previous meetings was thankfully abandoned this year, the dean attributed the
hike to rising costs and the relatively
low percentage of cost covered by tuition. Armstrong and Muller also pledged maintenance of financial aid.
And so the tradition continues.
The University's action is easy to attack popularly. After all, rising costs are
never welcome measures. Indeed, the
average undergraduate probably finds it
increasingly difficult to justify, if not
meet, the price of a private education.
On the other hand, if tuition actually
covers only a small proportion of the
price, as the administration's warmedover rhetoric implies, then it is difficult
to see what other choice administrators
have. Where will the difference come
from, if not in part from tuition? Clearly, maintaining that special Hopkins
quality is expensive, but letting it slide
would be even more costly.
Given that the University already considers undergraduates revenue raisers,
it is not a radical philosphical departure
to raise the amount each will pay. We
do applaud the two-tiered system. If the
tuition is to be raised, it is fair to allow
parents and students to adjust their expectations accordingly. After all, past
years have shown that tuition hikes,
however upsetting, are even more painful when more costly than anticipated.
So, it is with a sense of resignation
that we accept, however grudgingly, the
proposals that have been laid out before
us. In the final analysis, if we can continue our metaphor, the groundhog has
only a limited number of options to act
upon each time he comes out.

one hot option

Bob Nelson

Public Health Advisor Charlotte Kaufman.
by Scott Needle
Quick: what's the hottest major around? No, it's not biology,
BME, or IR, but public health,
according to Public Health Advisor Charlotte Kaufman.
Public Health has become a national priority as the public has
become more aware of health
issues such as smoking, AIDS,
and the environment. Public

health is simply working for and
with the public to develop and
maintain good health.
At Hopkins, undergrads interested in public health can pursue the Public Health Option in
conjunction with a natural, social,
or behavioral sciences major.
The Public Health Option involves taking the usual science requirements as well as some
courses at the School of Public
Health and Hygiene. Kaufman

describes it as "an amazing opportunity for young people to
have, to be involved in a school
of this quality."
The School of Public Health is
the oldest and most prestigious
public health school in the world.
It has students from around the
United States as well as from over
50 other countries. Some of its
twelve departments are almost as
hard to get into as the medical
school across the street, par-

ticularly epidemiology, maternal
and child health, population
dynamics, and environmental
sciences.
Graduates of the School of
Public Health can find jobs
almost immediately due to the
overwhelming demand for public
health professionals, such as.
health administrators and
epidemiologists. And first-year
salaries range from $20,000
(nutritionist) to $30,000 (health
management) and higher. Past
public health school graduates are
CEO's, presidents of companies,
directors, administrators, managers, and consultants.
A Master's in public health can
also give an immense edge in applying to med school, not to mention much more skill and
knowledge in practice. Kaufman
advises anyone even thinking of
med school to consider public
health. And under the Public
Health Option, students can get to
know faculty members at the
School, giving them an edge over
their peers.
Students interested in public
health should first browse
through materials in 241

Merganthaler.
By the second semester of
sophomore year, students should
have met with Kaufman to outline
options in detail. In their junior
year, students can apply for the
Bachelors/Masters program,
which guarantees admission to
the School and leaves half of the
senior year to starting progress
towards a Master's.
Even if students don't make it
into the School of Public Health,
there are 23 other public health
schools out there, including the
almost comparable Harvard,
Yale, Columbia, UC-Berkeley,
and Michigan.
Kaufman advises students to
consider public health early.
Kaufman, who has a Master's in
public health ('72), was Director
of Admissions and Registrar at
the School of Public Health from
1972-1986. She came to
Homewood this January and is
now the public health advisor.
Kaufman urges students to see
her. "We have this wonderful
resource that could be a life's opportunity for a number of
undergraduates who aren't quite
sure what they want to do."

Hockey loses two
by Phillip KouYoumdjian
The Johns Hopkins Blue Jays
resumed the hockey season with
two consecutive losses to
Bucknell on Thursday, January
26, and to Gettysburg the following Monday. Their record now
stands at two wins, five losses,
and one tie.
The Jays have had only one
practice since the January break,
which may explain their "lack of
intensity on the ice," according
to coach Steve Wirth after their
6-2 loss to Bucknell. Hopkins
played a fairly good defensive
game during the first two periods
and they were down by only one
goal going into the third period,
thanks to goals scored by center
Pat Gibbons and left wing Vinnie
Alfi. However, Bucknell
dominated the last period at the
drop of the puck. The Jays'
defense seemed to be one step
behind its opponents as they were
often caught too deep in
Bucknell's end, resulting in
several break-aways and many
two-on-ones.
If the Blue Jays lacked intensity in their first game, they lacked a lot more than that in their
game on Monday against Gettysburg. The entire game was
played at a sub-par level by
Hopkins, as they were out-hustled
and outsmarted by an obviously
less talented team.
"It's just another case of us losing to an inferior team," said
Wirth.
The Jays' biggest problem was
their inability to remove opposing players in front of their own
net. Instead of tying up the man
in front, the centers were hang-

ing at their blue line, waiting for
an outlet pass, which unfortunately never came. This gave Gettysburg two, sometimes even
three, extra scoring opportunities
on goalie Dave Bower. Bower,
despite constant pressure, played
a solid game and made over thirty saves. Another problem was
that the wings often got caught
deep in their offensive zone and
failed to backcheck. As a result,
Gettysburg then broke out with
two-on-ones.
Hopkins did show flashes of
brilliance as Pat Gibbons scored
two goals within one minute, the
second one set up by a beautiful
pass from defenseman Mark
Koren. However, it was, once
again, a case of too little, too late
as Gettysburg skated away with
an easy 6-2 victory.
Although
Hopkins
is
guaranteed a spot in the play-offs,
the situation would be completely different had they not been
selected to host the post-season
games. Their only two victories
have been against Western
Maryland, a team that is weak in
almost all aspects of the game. If
the Blue Jays want to start being
recognized as a legitimate hockey
team by others in the MasonDixon Hockey League, they will
have to begin by beating teams
with less talent, such as
Gettysburg.
The Blue Jays now take a two
week hiatus and will return to action on Thursday, February 16.

come to the game at the Mount
Pleasant Ice Arena, on the corner
of Northern Parkway and Hillen
Road.
